content.rendered:
It is unusually ironic, how the loudest thing to ever exist is silence. The universe dwells in silence, albeit known. But how contradicting it is, as loud as a human can be, the only thing that completes him is silence. Silence never speaks, silence screams; screams in every language known and every language that was to ever exist which is now is dead and long forgotten. Silence is the undisputed although uncrowned King of a deeper reality. It’s amusing to watch men searching for ways to end silence, forging it to be awkward or uncontrolled. But that is the known beauty of silence, it’s uncontrivable, and uncontrollable.

 Humans have become superficial, never searching for a deeper horizon, never seeing past what meets the eye, however silence? Silence challenges men, intimidates them, forcing them to develop perceptions deeper than reality and this…this makes it ‘awkward.’ People, who’ve carved their ways past the superficial levels, people who search for a deeper level of understanding, they have come to admit the beauty of silence. We, although appreciate the deep-rooted silence, we have never been able to see past the leaves of this mammoth tree. Sitting with someone, not sharing the words, but sharing yourself, letting the silence scream, letting the universe mingle with the gluttonous screams of the silence, creating an unparallel symphony of so many words, that is a blessed moment. It is blessed because we have come to realise, it is so rare. Words are abused, anyway.

The silence of the cold winter nights, where the wind howls in the distant; the silence of the good old rainy days, where the only sound that meets your ears is the silence of the raindrops. These moments are when the silence screams the most, demands all of your being. The silence in us, it knows all the answers, it knows all the ways, it just needs to breathe, you need to let it breathe, let the silence communicate.

And Gulzar Sahab has quoted, “Silence is an echo of my voice. There is always an inherent silence in a poem. The poet hides behind that silence and yet he is loud enough to be echoed by those who share his heart beats. My silence is more eloquent than my voice. “

 Have you ever had that ardent desire to be smothered by silence, to let it consume you so gloriously that it rubs the fog right off and makes you see past the fake sonority of the world? If , then take a chance and let yourself inhale the silence, let it speak to you, let it uncover the secrets that you want answers to.

Jaahnavi Pandya

BDS 4th Sem

Vrushali Ranadive

મારા કાર્યકાળનો અંતિમ લેખ્ લખવા બેઠો ને કલમ આગળ ચલાવી ન શક્યો. લેખ્ એક જ છે પણ મનમાં આવતા વિચારો અનેક છે.

ક્યાં વિષય પર લખવું ને શું લખવું ના દ્વંધ યુદ્ધમાં સમય ચાલ્યો જતો. કોઈ એક કાર્યનું પ્રારંભનું અને અંતનું પગથિયું હંમેશા મુઝવણમાં મૂકી દેતું હોય છે. ખરું ને! આ તમે પણ અનુભવ્યું હશે.

ઘોર અંધારાં ઓરડામાં પ્રકાશનું કિરણ કેવું દ્રશ્યમાન થાય. બસ! કંઇક એવું જ ત્વરિત વિચારનું બિંદુ મારા મન પર આરોહણ થયું. સતત વંટોળિયાની જેમ મસ્તિષ્ક માં ભ્રમણ કરતા વિચારોમાં એક વાત કાયમ હતી કે અંતિમ લખાણ તો કોઈ શ્રેષ્ઠ વિશે જ લખવું કે જેની તુલના આ વિશ્વમાં શક્ય નથી. અને તે એટલે’.-  “માતૃભૂમિ”. માનવી ગમે તેટલી પ્રગતિ કરે પરંતુ તેને પોતાની માતૃભૂમિ પર સદા ગર્વ હોય છે. તેથી જ તો કહેવાયું છે કે “जननी जन्मभूमिश्च स्वर्गादपि गरीयसी ।” જનની અને જન્મભૂમિ સ્વર્ગથી પણ શ્રેષ્ઠ છે.

માતૃભૂમિ વિશે લખવાનું શરૂ કર્યું પછી તો અગણિત વિચારોના પ્રવાહમાં કલમ લસરતી ગઈ. એક પછી એક શબ્દાવલી મનની બહાર આવતી ગઈ. આ જ તો છે માતૃભૂમિનો અજાયબી જાદુ. ખબર ન પડતા કેટલુંય સમજાવી જાય છે આ માતૃભૂમિ.

થોડાક જ દિવસો પહેલા મને મારી માતૃભૂમિ એટલે કે મારા ગામ તરફ જવાનો મને મોકો મળ્યો. મારા ગામ સુઘી પહોંચતા દરેેક ક્ષણ મને ઉમળકો હતો- માતૃભૂમિ ને સ્પર્શ કરવાનો, પ્રકૃતિને નિહાળવાનો અને બાળપણની યાદો વાગોળવાનો. એક એવી જગ્યા જ્યાં સુખ જ સુખ. શહેરના વિકસિત રસ્તાઓની ગતિમાં જેટલો આનંદ નથી ને તેટલો આનંદ મને મારા ગામની પગદંડી પર ટહેલવામાં આવે છે. માતૃભૂમિની માટીમાં સુગંધ છે, જેને પણ સ્પર્શ મળે તે હળવો થઈ જાય છે. અજાણતા જ મનનાં ઘણા પ્રશ્નો આપો આપ ઉકેલાય જાય છે. મેં સૂક્ષ્મ વિચાર કર્યો કે સમય જતાં વ્યક્તિ વિકાસની હરોળમાંથી બહાર ન આવી શક્યો. સમય જતાં લોકો લાભાર્થી બન્યા એટલે કે જ્યાં લાભ મળ્યો ત્યાં પહોંચી ગયા. અને આ હરોળ માં હું પણ આવ્યો જ . મારા સ્વાર્થ માટે મેં મારી માતૃભૂમિ ને છોડી દીધી હતી થોડાક જ વર્ષો પહેલા. પરંતુ આ માતૃભૂમિએ જાણે કે ગામ છોડીને ચાલ્યા જતાં પગલાંઓને ઓળખી લીધા ન હોય તેમ વર્તવા લાગે છે. આવા તોહ કેટલાંય લોકો આ ભૂમિ છોડી ને બીજે વસવાટ કર્યો હશે પરંતુ તે ઓળખી જરૂર લે છે અને ત્વરિત સ્વીકારીને તે પોતાના ખોળામાં બેસાડી દે છે. કેવી નિઃસ્વાર્થ ભાવના! સાચે કહું તો માતૃવાત્સલ્ય, કરુણા, અને પ્રેમ તમને અહીં દૃષ્ટિમાન થતો નજરે પડે. માતૃભૂમિ(ગામ) તરફના માર્ગો પર ગયો ત્યાં પણ મને એકલતાનો અનુભવ ન થયો. ગામની એક ઊંચાંન જગ્યાએ જઈ જોયું તો ગામ બદલાઈ ગયેલું જરૂર હતું પણ તેમાંથી આવતા તરંગો તદ્દન અનુરૂપ હતા. પ્રકૃતિને નજરે ખીલતી જોવી હોય તો માતૃભૂમિને મળવું પડે.જો ખુલ્લાં હૃદયથી હસવું હોય તો પણ માતૃભૂમિ ને મળવું પડે. માતૃભૂમિના ખોળે બેસતા સહજ બે પંક્તિ લખાઈ-

 

‘વર્ણવું છું હું મારી માતૃભૂમિ ને;

જ્યાં સહજ અગણિત કિસ્સાઓનું વર્ણન થઈ જાય,

મૂલ્ય અંકાય નહિ આ ભૂમિ નું!

જેના ફક્ત સ્પર્શથી જીવન ધન્ય થઈ જાય.’……

 

જેમ માતૃભૂમિની ઓળખથી આપણી આંખ અશ્રુઓથી ભીની થાય છે તેમ આ માતૃભૂમિ પર વસતા લોકોનો સ્વભાવ પણ કંઇક જુદો જ છે. ઓચિંતું હાસ્ય પણ મિત્રતામાં પરિણમે. થોડાંક જ સમયમાં ત્યાંના લોકોથી થતી મિત્રતા પણ ઘણું શીખવી જાય છે. હું માતૃભૂમિની મહેક માણી રહ્યો હતો ને ઘડિયાળમાં જોયું તો પાછો ફરવાનો સમય આવી ગયો હતો. આવી માતૃભૂમિને છોડીને જવાનું મન ન હતું! આવ્યા ત્યારનો ઉલ્લાસ ક્ષણવારમાં જમીનદોસ્ત થઇ ગયો. દશે દિશાઓ જાણે સંકોચાઈ ગઈ હોય, ફૂલો મુર્જયા હોય અને રસ્તાઓ જાણે સુપ્ત થયા હોય એવો અનુભવ અંતરમાં થવા લાગ્યો. કલમ હવે અટકવા લાગી હતી. આજે હું અહીંથી ચાલ્યો જાવ છું પણ ફરી પાછો આવીશ ત્યારે મને વિશ્વાસ છે કે એ જ ઉમળકા સાથે માતૃભૂમિ મને ફરી સ્વીકારશે. કેમકે એક માતા પોતાના દીકરાને તેના પ્રેમથી વંચિત ના રાખી શકે.

content.rendered:
As I sit on my desk writing a final article being in a beautiful family-Connect, I wonder whom I should dedicate it to. Should I write this article as an ode to all my seniors and colleagues? Or should I write it as a thank you note to everyone who inspired me to write or even pushed me to do better. I heartily wanted to ink some words about the good times I’ve had being a part of Connect as well as the university but something really told me to write about someone who didn’t inspire me to write, rather had been a perfect audience of my work.Someone who was always the first to read my article as soon as it got uploaded online and suggested that the website should have a ‘like and comment’ option so he could give a feedback. Someone I lost in september 2020, my grandfather.

I still remember the days when he took me for evening walks and introduced me to the passers-by as his granddaughter when I was a child. The theory of time really perplexes me sometimes because as I grew up, he did the same to proudly introduce me to his friends. The only difference was that this time I hung out with my friends and the grand father-daughter duo just happened to stumble across each other. If only I could defy reality to spend more time with him.

He wasn’t only a reader but also a passionate writer who always asked if he could get a Connect membership. He’d tell me how he bragged about my articles to his friends whenever I shared the links. If only I could get my best subscriber again.

Although most of my friends found him quite intimidating, he was really a sweet guy. He liked to personally get to know my friends so he could know whom to terrorize the next time.To be honest he found it funny as his terror was also his pride. But like I said, he was also a sweet guy. I really cherish the times when he asked for my help to solve silly little things as he often got mired up using a smartphone. My eyes get dewy when a friend shares a similar incident with their grandparents. If only I could be the “tech girl” again.

I cannot help but shed tears when my grandmother would tell the tales about their love marriage, how it was so tough in those times and how he stood against all the odds to always achieve something he wanted. Unlike other guardians, he said his mantra was to ‘just take a nap man’ and start fresh the next day whenever you’re stuck. He not only mentored his children but also hundreds of other people with his work and diligence. If only I could book those mentoring slots again.

In spite of being the busiest member of the family, he always had the time for everyone.Never missed a chance to get us our favourite snacks or take the family to trips and even take part in our jocular shenanigans. To him, nothing else mattered and his family was his pride.This is what I truly respect him for. I can’t help but shiver and whimper while I write, if only his family was with him for the last time.

I like to think he’s on a long trip to the snowy mountains, as he often visited those and will be back soon with a silly explanation for the blur photos he managed to take. Only if he could.

I guess I’ll just take a nap now.


Priya Rathod

IT 7th Sem

content.rendered:
Andrew and I have been inseparable since the day we met at the theatres. I was simply doingmy job like the director had asked me to when I heard him yell, “I love Casper!”. He was a smallboy of three who was grinning from ear to ear. Once the credits rolled over, I sneaked out of thescreen discreetly and followed him. He had held his parent’s hand while he excitedly shared hisappreciation for the movie and its ghosts. My translucent chest had swelled up with pride. I sawAndrew looking back a couple oftimes, probably sensing my presence as he left the complex.But I would quickly hide behind a wall or a pillar. But he managed to catch me and threw a smilein my direction. His dad sat in the driver seat while his mum tucked him in his baby seat in theback of his car. Andrew signalled me to hurry up so I hastily snuck past his mum and sat next tohim. Both of us snickered as the car drove on, and that is how our friendship began.

We used to play for hours at his house. He was still learning how to use the swing set in hiscommunity playground in the early phase of our friendship. I remember how sad he was whenall his friends could swing by themselves while he had to rely on his parents to push him everyfew seconds. I could not bear to see him look hopeless so I would sneak out of the bush andpush his swing a couple of times before hiding behind the bush again. I can still recall hislaughter as he went high up in the air.

Everything was perfect until he began going to school. I had never been away fromhim for solong. When I told Andrew how much I missed playing with him all day, he asked me to hideinside his school bag and promised to take me with him the following day. His school was huge;there were plenty of other kids as well, more than those inthe park. I used to sit under his desksuch that his classmates won’t notice me. During playtime, a group of kids played outside whilesome stayed inside to play with toys. Andrew told me how he was afraid to make friends andhow he missed his mum dearly.I remember grabbing his hand and pulling him towards theplayground. Once there, I asked him to show the kids some of his spiderman stickers. He wasshy at first but mustered up some courage and walked towards them. Within minutes everyonehad surrounded him to look at those sparkling stickers. From the sea of tiny heads, his grinningface popped out while his bright eyes thanked me for my genius idea.

Apart from this major success, I would not say school was a good place for friends like me. MyAndrew spent most of his time interacting with his classmates or drawing masterpieces on anA4 sheet of paper. He was a good kid and tried to talk to me every chance he got, but he couldnot give me the attention I once received. This made me commit the biggest mistake of my life-I told him I wanted to stay at his house and not come to his school anymore because I gotbored. I felt I would enjoy playing with his hot wheels and barbies more than with him at school.It was fun for a few days, not having to be squished between his books in his bag or squattingunder his desk but getting to sleep in his soft bed till noon and eating his favourite cookies. Butthat meant I would not see Andrew for hours and had to stay alone in his massive scary house.Little did I knowthat what was about to happen was scarier than the empty house.

Within a few weeks, I started noticing how distant Andrew had been from me. He no longerlooked around for me in the park, instead he tried to find his friends there. Even during dinner,Andrew would not talk to me much. The worst part was that he had forgotten about our late-night stargazing sessions since he used to be exhausted by bedtime. He started bringing hisfriends over more often. I had tried talking to some of his friends, but I think they were a littlesnooty since they never responded. I even tried copying their mannerisms so that Andrew wouldnotice me but his eyes seemed to look past my translucent body.

I would have still lived this way if I had not noticed how my once big bulbous head had nowstarted shrinking while my little pinky finger had disappeared. There was only one explanationfor this problem; Andrew no longer needed me. I was heartbroken. I was supposed to be angryat him for robbing me of his friendship, but all I could feel was pain. I used to think about what I could have done differently to avoid this problem. But I soon realised it was of no use. After all, I was just an imaginary friend.

Devashree Katarkar

હું બાળપણથી જ ક્રિકેટ પ્રત્યે રુચિ ધરાવતો હતો. અલબત્ત, મને હજી પણ યાદ છે 2014 ની એ ક્ષણ જ્યારે ઇન્ડિયન સુપર લીગની શરૂઆત થઈ હતી અને વર્લ્ડ ક્લાસ ખેલાડીઓ, કોચ, મેનેજરથી સજ્જ આ લીગ એ મારા જેવા ઘણા યુવાઓને ભારતીય ફૂટબોલ પ્રત્યે પ્રેરિત કર્યા હતા. આ સમય દરમિયાન હું એફસી ગોવાની રમવાની સ્ટાઇલથી ખૂબ જ પ્રભાવિત થઈ ગયો હતો અને તમારો ચાહક બની ગયો હતો. તે સિઝનમાં તો તમારું પ્રદર્શન પણ ખૂબ જ અવ્વલ દરજ્જાનું રહ્યું હતું તેમ છતાં સેમી-ફાઇનલમાં પેનલ્ટી શુટઆઉટમાં ખૂબ જ નજીવા અંતરે હાર નો સામનો કરવો પડ્યો હતો, ત્યારે હું પણ હતાશ થઈ ગયો હતો. જોકે ત્યારબાદ આ લીગની આવનારી આવૃત્તિઓમાં બ્રાઝિલીયન કોચ ઝીકોના માર્ગદર્શન હેઠળ તમારી સિદ્ધિઓનો પાર જ રહ્યો ન હતો. દરેક આવૃત્તિઓમાં લગભગ પ્લેઓફ સુધી પહોંચવાની આશા રાખવી એ તો મારી માટે સામાન્ય વાત થઈ ગઈ હતી. એક ફૂટબોલ ફેન તરીકે પોતાની પ્રિય ટીમને આક્રમક, કુશળ અને સંતુલિત પ્રદર્શન કરીને એક પછી એક સફળતા હાંસલ કરતા જોવી એ મારા માટે તો એક સ્વપ્ન સમાન જ હતું. આ સમય દરમિયાન હું તમારી સાથે એટલો બધો જોડાઈ ગયો હતો કે ફક્ત દરેક મેચ જ નહિ પરંતુ તમારી દરેક મેચ પહેલાની ટીમ અપડેટ્સ, ટીમ વિશ્લેષણની પણ જાણકારી રાખતો.

ભારતીય યુવા પ્રતીભાઓને સતત આંતરરાષ્ટ્રીય કક્ષાની તાલીમ અને અનુભવ દ્વારા પ્રોત્સાહન આપીને તેમની રમતને વધુ સારી બનાવવી એ મુખ્ય બાબત છે કે જે મારી જેવા અનેક ચાહકોને તમારી સાથે જકડી રાખે છે.આજે પણ જ્યારે આપણે ભારતીય ફૂટબોલ ટીમ તરફ નજર કરીએ ત્યારે મહત્વના મિડફીલ્ડર્સ ખેલાડીઓ બ્રાન્ડોન ફર્નાન્ડિઝ, ગ્લેન માર્ટિન્ઝ, ફોરવર્ડ ખેલાડી ઈશાન પંડિતા અને  મંદારરાવ દેસાઈ જેવા બેક લાઈન ખેલાડીઓ એફસી ગોવામાં જ ઉછરેલી યુવા પ્રતિભા છે. ફૂટબોલ એક એવી રમત છે કે જ્યાં દરેક મેચ ટુર્નામેન્ટમાં તમારું ભાવિ નક્કી કરી શકે છે. અને ઇન્ડિયન સુપર લીગ જેવી સ્પર્ધાત્મક ટુર્નામેન્ટમાં પણ ભારતીય  યુવા ખેલાડીઓને 1-2 મેચ માં સામાન્ય દેખાવ છતાં પ્લેઈંગ ઇલેવન માં સ્થાન આપી તેમને આત્મવિશ્વાસ આપવો એ ખરેખર મારી દ્રષ્ટિ એ ખૂબ જ અગત્યનું પગલું હતું.

મને આજે પણ યાદ છે એ 2019/20 ની ISL આવૃત્તિમાં સમગ્ર ટીમના   ઉત્કૃષ્ટ દેખાવ, કોચ સર્જિયો લોબેરાની આક્રમક સ્પેનિશ શૈલીની રમતથી લીગ શિલ્ડના વિજેતા બન્યા અને આ સાથે જ એફસી ગોવા AFC ચેમ્પિયન્સ લીગમાં સ્થાન હાંસલ કરનર ભારતીય ઈતિહાસમાં પ્રથમ ટીમ બની. આ ક્ષણ ફક્ત મારા માટે જ નહિં પરંતુ સમગ્ર દેશ માટે અવિસ્મરણીય રહેશે.આજે પણ જ્યારે હું તમારા આવા સંસ્મરણો યાદ કરું છું ત્યાર મારા નેત્રપટલ પર તેજ દૃશ્યો જાણે જીવંત પ્રસારિત થતા હોય તેમ છવાઈ જાય છે.

સીઝન 2020/21 ની શરૂઆત પહેલા તમારા મેનેજમેન્ટના જે ટીમના કોચ અને મહત્વના ખેલાડીઓ અંગે ના નિર્ણયો હતા તે ખરેખર હચમચાવી નાખે તેવા હતા. પાછલી સીઝનના ખૂબ જ પ્રશંસનીય અને અકલ્પય પ્રદર્શન કરવા છતાં મતભેદો ને કારણે કોચ સહીત ટીમ ના મોટા ભાગના ખેલાડીઓને તમારા દ્રારા જાળવી રાખવામાં આવ્યા ન હતા. જે મારા માટે ભારે આંચકા સમાન હતું. હું એ વાત સમજુ છું કે કોઈ ક્લબ માટે તેના ચાહકો જે ખેલાડી ઈચ્છે છે તેને ટીમમાં સમાવવો શક્ય નથી. અને આ વાત સહજ પણ છે. કોચ અને ખેલાડીઓમાં ધરખમ ફેરફારોથી હું નિરાશ હતો. ટીમમાં સમાવેશ થયેલા નવા ખેલાડીઓ ISLમાં તમારી ઉપલબ્ધીઓ રૂપી વારસાને જાળવી શકશે કે નહિ તે પ્રશ્ન સતત મને મૂંઝવી રહ્યો હતો. પરંતુ જેમ જેમ ટુર્નામેન્ટ આગળ વધતી ગઈ તેમ તેમ એફસી ગોવાએ પોતાની રમતથી સૌને સ્તબ્ધ કરી દીધા. યુવા સ્પેનિશ કોચ જુઆન ફેરેંડો અને તેમની વ્યૂહાત્મકતાનું સચોટ અનુસરણ કરતા કેપ્ટન એડું બેડિયા અને સર્વોચ્ચ ગોલ સ્કોરર ઇગોર અંગૂલો અને ઓરટીઝ મેન્ડોઝાએ તો બધાને પોતાના પ્રદર્શન દ્રારા સ્તબ્ધ જ કરી દીધા. ત્યારે મને તમારા મેનેજમેન્ટના નિર્ણયોની યોગ્યતા જાણવા મળી. મારા મતે વિદેશી અને ભારતીય ખેલાડીઓ વચ્ચેનું યોગ્ય તાલમેલ જ તમને બાકી બધી ટીમ કરતા વિશેષ બનાવે છે.

AFC ચેમ્પિયન્સ લીગમાં પ્રથમ વાર એક ભારતીય ફૂટબોલ ક્લબ તરીકે સ્થાન મેળવ્યા બાદ પણ તેમાં જે તમારો દેખાવ રહ્યો છે તેણે સમગ્ર દુનિયામાં ભારતીય ફૂટબોલનું નામ રોશન કર્યું છે. એશિયન રનર્સઅપ પર્સપોલીસ એફસી જેવી કદાવર ટીમ સામે પણ આપણી ટીમની ધૈર્યપૂર્વક ડિફેન્સીવ અને સન્માનજનક રમત એ મારા માટે આંતરરાષ્ટ્રીય સ્તરે ક્લબનું શ્રેષ્ઠ પ્રદર્શન રહ્યું છે. હું આવનારા સમયમાં પણ તમે ઇન્ડિયન સુપર લીગ અને એશિયા સ્તરે સફળતા હાંસલ કરો તેવી આશા ધરાવું છું. મને એક એફસી ગોવા અને ફૂટબોલ ફેન અત્યાર સુધી તમે જે અસંખ્ય અવિસ્મરણીય રમતની પળો આપી છે તે માટે હંમેશા આભારી રહીશ.

આ ઉપરાંત હું  એફસી ગોવાના હોમ ગ્રાઉન્ડ ફતોર્ડા સ્ટેડિયમના માહોલ નો અને ત્યાંના ચાહકો નો ખાસ કરીને ગૌર્સ આર્મીનો પણ દીવાનો છું. મને તો એ જાણી ને જ નવાઈ લાગે છે કે ગોવામાં મેચ હોય ત્યારે તો સહજ છે કે ફુલ સપોર્ટ હોય ચાહકોનો પરંતુ અન્ય સ્થળે મેચ હોય તો પણ આખી ટ્રેન ભરી ને ચાહકો ટીમના સપોર્ટ માટે જાય છે.મારી પણ એક ચાહક તરીકે ઇચ્છા છે કે હું પણ એક દિવસ એફસી ગોવાની મેચ સ્ટેડિયમમાં જોવા જઈશ.

Vedant Rajyaguru

content.rendered:
“Can I sit here?”-To the person that I asked this to on the first day of my new school, who are you? You introduced yourself to me, I introduced myself to you, I talked to you as I’d talk to anyother stranger, unbeknownst of the great journey ahead of us. Until you were not a stranger anymore, you were someone I respect, someone who’d leave me awestruck with your thoughts on the world and the people within.

I would look down on people, unable to comprehend why people do what they do. I thought you were different, one of a kind that you meet once in a lifetime. You made me realize I was wrong. You were just someone who saw the best in others, in stark contrast to what I did. I metyou, I listened to you and I realized the greatness in people. I remembered everyone I ever met,everyone I looked down upon, and realized how deeply mistaken I was.

To the person who opened my eyes, this is who you are. One among the many that I walked onthe path of life with, the one who moulded me into a better being. Theflow of time will not allow us to walk on the same path forever, but this time we share together will never change.It’s immutable, constant and mine forever. Carved into my mind, impossible to forget.You will be with me-in my thoughts and actions, and the way I live my life. And I’ll be there with you.

All the people I have ever met are still with me. Thousands of fractions of other people’s livesreside within me and a part of me resides within them. It made me who I am. I wonder who they are today.To all the people who led me to this point in time, I am grateful. If we meet again, will we remember the path we shared? Will we go on to create something better? I amcertain we will. To everyone in my past, present and future-let’s meet. I want to create a beautiful path for us to walk upon, so that when we say our last goodbyes, we’d be a better version of ourselves. I want nothing more.

Khadija Sidhpuri

AUTHOR
CE 7th Sem

Naman Rajani

DESIGNER
IT 3rd Sem

content.rendered:
In the sweaty summers of May, a girl in her bright peachy dress was sauntering in her vineyard and speaking out loud to herself, making notes of what her rest of the day should look like, of thinking about how beautiful the bees look and how confusing quantum physics really is. People were glancing at her awkwardly but she didn’t particularly mind and continued her soliloquy pacing vigorously.

Yep, that girl was me.

My mind and I have the deepest bond, we could just never stop conversing! And sometimes, it comes out loud to make the people around me rather gasp or gawk at me. But that never stops me, or my mind for that matters. Is it just me or does anybody else feel the same way is my biggest question and my mind and I have had huge discussions over this topic a dozen times. There have been occasions where you may be chattering with a person face to face but there is more you like to express which only goes in your mind. It always happens after an argument that I feel I could have counterattacked my opponent by saying something else rather than what I said earlier.

I’ve always found myself pondering over the fact of how amazing our mind functions. The irony that knowing how a mind functions itself needs a mind is mind-blowing. To deepen my knowledge about the phenomenon of talking to oneself, I found some intriguing inferences online. It said in an article that inner speech isn’t bound by the conventions of verbal speech and due to this very fact inner speech cites an average of 4000 words per minute which is ten times faster than verbal and thus obviously more condensed because we don’t need to use full sentences to talk to ourselves, because well we know what we mean without the use of proper grammar and punctuations.

Everyone loves having little time to themselves in a day doing nothing and lazing around. But your mind never leaves you. You could be doing something as mundane as looking for the right keys from the jumbled ones in your hands on a hectic Monday morning or could be potentially working your ass off for a pivotal event; at any given such time, the urge to talk to yourself could happen. Hence, everyone has the habit of talking to themselves. No one can deny it.

I get my idea to write, to play music unknowingly through my gossiping with my mind. An ‘ad nauseam behavior’, my baby sister would mock me, but don’t we all love our little unknown chit-chats with our wandering minds?

Gautam Gandhi

AUTHOR
EC 7th Sem

Vrushali Ranadive

DESIGNER
CE 2nd Sem

Sruthi Cheruvullil

content.rendered:
Why is it that the left glove simply won’t fit the right hand as well as it fits the left? In science, this property is referred to as chirality. Left hands and right hands are almost perfect mirror images of each other. But whatever way they are twisted and turned, they cannot be superimposed onto each other. Just like hands are chiral, molecules can be chiral, too. In fact, most molecules in the cells of living organisms, such as DNA, are chiral. Unlike hands, however, that usually come in pairs of left and right, the molecules of life almost exclusively occur in either their “left-handed” or their “right-handed” version. They are called homochiral, as researchers say. This molecular homochirality is a characteristic property of life or a biosignature.

“When light is reflected by biological matter, a part of the light’s electromagnetic waves travel in either clockwise or counterclockwise spirals. This phenomenon is called circular polarization and is caused by the biological matter’s homochirality. Similar spirals of light are not produced by abiotic non-living nature,” says the first author of the study Lucas Patty, who is a MERMOZ postdoctoral researcher at the University of Bern and member of the NCCR PlanetS. Measuring this circular polarization is challenging because the signal is quite faint and typically makes up less than one percent of the light that is reflected. To measure this, as part of the MERMOZ project, a team of scientists from the University of Bern and of the National Centre of Competence in Research (NCCR) PlanetS developed a dedicated device called a spectropolarimeter. It consists of a camera equipped with special lenses and receivers capable of separating the circular polarization from the rest of the light. They have now succeeded in detecting this signature from a distance of 2kilometers and at a velocity of 70 kph. Jonas Kühn, MERMOZ project manager of the University of Bern and co-author of the study that has just been published in the journal Astronomy and Astrophysics, says: “The significant advance is that these measurements have been performed in a platform that was moving, vibrating and that we still detected these biosignatures in a matter of seconds.

“Using this device dubbed as FlyPol, they demonstrated that within mere seconds of measurements they could differentiate between grass fields, forests and urban areas from a fast moving helicopter. The measurements readily show living matter exhibiting the characteristic polarization signals, while roads, for example, do not show any significant circular polarization signals. With the current setup, they are even capable of detecting signals coming from algae in lakes. The next step the scientists now hope to take is to perform similar detections from the International Space Station (ISS), looking down at the Earth. That will allow them to assess the detectability of planetary-scale biosignatures. This step will be decisive to enable the search for life in and beyond our Solar System using polarization, and it can also offer valuable complementary information in Earth remote sensing

Snigdha Lokre

શ્રી પ્રેમાનંદ કૃષ્ણરામ ભટ્ટ,

            આપના અવનવા કાવ્યો, પંક્તિઓ સ્મરણ કરીને આજે હું, આપને સંબોધીને કંઈક લખવા ઈચ્છું છું. ઉપરાંત તમારાં જીવન થી પ્રેરિત થઈ કંઈક શીખવા ઈચ્છું છું. આજે એક ગુજરાતી કવિને નજર સમક્ષ રાખી , જો હું કંઈક સારા લેખન લખી શકું, તો તે મારા માટે  ભાગ્યની વાત ગણાય.

          આપની ઘણી લઘુકૃતિઓથી હું પરિચિત છું , જેમકે ‘શામળશાનો વિવાહ’ , ‘દાણલીલા’ , ‘બાળલીલા વ્રજવેલ’. પરંતુ તે વાત ન વિસરાય કે , ગુજરાતી સાહિત્યમાં સૌપ્રથમ આખ્યાનોની શરૂઆત કરનાર બીજું કોઈ નહિ, સ્વયં પ્રેમાનંદજી આપ હતા. આપના આખ્યાનોના હું શું ગુણ ગાઉં? અલૌકિક રચનાઓથી ભરપૂર આખ્યાનો પૈકી ત્રણ આખ્યાનો વિષે હું જાણું છું. ‘સુદામાચરિત’ , ‘મામેરું’ , ‘નળાખ્યાન’. આ પૈકી એક આખ્યાન જે મને ખૂબ ગમ્યું હતું તે છે, ‘નળાખ્યાન’. રાજા નળ અને તેમની પત્ની દમયંતીના પ્રેમ અને લગ્નજીવનની કથાનું કાલ્પનિક વર્ણન અને જીવિત ભાવો મને ખરેખર અસરકારક રહ્યા. આવા અવનવા આખ્યાનોની રચના કરવા બદલ તે જમાનામાં લોકો આપને ‘રાસકવિ’ તરીકે ઓળખતા, તે મને સહજ લાગે છે. અને આપનો ઇતિહાસ વધુ જાણવા માટે પ્રેરિત કરે છે. વાર્તાઓ, કાવ્યરચના, આખ્યાનો આ તમામ રચનાઓ કરતી વખતે એક વાત ધ્યાનમાં રાખવી જરૂરી છે કે, સાંભળનાર કે વાંચનાર તેમાં ભળી જાય અને સારી રીતે ભાવાર્થ સમજી શકે. તમારી ભાષાશક્તિ અને રસનિરુપણ શક્તિએ આપના કાર્યને વધુ મૂલ્યવાન બનાવ્યું હતું. અને આ એક આપની ખાસિયતથી હું પરિચિત છું. કંઈક તો મહત્વતા આપના લેખનોમાં રહી જ હશે , બાકી તે સમયના મુઘલરાજા ઉપરાંત  ઔરંગઝેબ આપને ‘મહાકવિ પ્રેમાનંદ ‘ કહી સંબોધે તે વાત કંઈક અલગ જ ઉચ્ચતા ધરાવે છે. અને આપના આખ્યાનો, આપના ગુણગાનો સાંભળ્યા બાદ મને ગુજરાતી હોવા ઉપર ખૂબ ગર્વ થાય છે. 

         આપના ઇતિહાસની જાણકારી અનુસાર, આપનું એક કવિ બનવાનું કારણ શું હશે તે મને સ્પષ્ટ નથી થતું. પરંતુ આપના ગુજરાતી સાહિત્યમાં તમામ સમર્પણો જાણે મારી આંખો  સામેનું ધુમ્મસ દૂર કરે છે. જો કોઈ કલાકાર પોતાની કલામાં ખૂબ જ ઉત્તમ હોય અને તેનાથી લોકોને કંઈક જાણવા કે શીખવા મળે, તો તે  નજરે આવવાનું જ. અને પોતાની આ કલાને લીધે જ લોકો આપને ‘કવિ શિરોમણી’ કહીને સંબોધતા તે વાત યોગ્યતાને પાત્ર છે. હું આપના વિશે વધુ ને વધુ જાણતા થાકતી નથી. આપની રસનિરુપણ શક્તિ વિશે મને સાંભળવામાં આવ્યું છે કે કોઇ આખ્યાનનું કથન કરતી વખતે એક રસમાંથી બીજા રસમાં સરકી જઈને અલગ જ જમાવટ કરવી તે આપની એક અલગ જ વૃત્તિ કહેવાતી. માણ દ્વારા કથન કરવામાં કુશળ તેવા મહાકવિ પ્રેમાનંદજી આપ , માનવમન અને માનવસ્વભાવની ઊંડાણે સમજ રાખનાર અદભુત આખ્યાનકાર હતા. અને લેખનો દ્વારા લોકોના મનને જગાવી રાખવામાં ખૂબ પ્રસિદ્ધ હતા. આ વાતને લીધે હું આપથી ખૂબ જ પ્રભાવિત થઇ છું.       

            કનૈયાલાલ માણેકલાલ મુનશી એક જાણીતા લેખક ઉપરાંત એક રાજકીય કાર્યકર્તા હતા. ગુજરાતનું નામ ગર્વથી ઊંચું રાખવામાં તેમનો ખૂબ ફાળો રહ્યો છે. આપના મહાનલેખોથી પ્રભાવિત થઈ , ક. મા. મુનશીએ આપને ‘ ગુજરાતની રંગભૂમિ ઉપરનો નાનો વ્યાસ’ કહ્યું હતું, તે આપની અલૌકિક કલાને આશરે જાય છે. આપ મહાકવિ શા માટે કહેવાયા તે હવે મને સંપૂર્ણ રીતે સ્પષ્ટ થાય છે. દેવોમાં પહેલું પૂજન જેનું થાય તેવા ‘ગણપતિ’ અને વિદ્યાની દેવી ‘સરસ્વતી’ આ બંને દેવતાઓનું સ્મરણ કોઈ પણ કાર્ય પહેલા કરવું, તે આપણા સંસ્કારો, આપણી સંસ્કૃતિ તથા આપણી એક હિન્દુધર્મની ઓળખ છે. અને આપ પોતાના દરેક કાર્યોની શરૂઆત આ દેવતાઓને આંખ અને હૃદયના ભીતર રાખી કરતા, તે વાત આપની પોતાની સંસ્કૃતિ પ્રત્યેની વિનમ્રતાનું પ્રતિબિંબ આપે છે. પહેલાના જમાનામાં ભાષાને અનુલક્ષીને વાર્તાઓ, લેખનો, કાવ્યગ્રંથો , આ તમામ રચનાઓને ગુજરાતી ભાષા કરતા બીજી ભાષાઓમાં વધુ ગૌરવ મળતું. આથી આપે ગુજરાતી ભાષાને અન્ય ભાષા જેવું ગૌરવ ના મળે, ત્યાં સુધી પાઘડી ન પહેરવાની પ્રતિજ્ઞા લીધી હતી. આ કિસ્સો પોતાની માતૃભાષાના સન્માન માટે એક ખૂબ મોટું પગલું ગણી શકાય. આમ , આપે પોતાની લેખનવૃત્તિ સાથે સાથે માતૃભાષા ગુજરાતીને પણ એક ઊંચો દરજ્જો અપાવ્યો. આ વાતથી આપ એક મહાકવિની સાથે સાથે મહાત્મા પણ હતા તે મને સિદ્ધ થાય છે . કહેવતોનો ભંડાર હતું જાણે આપનું મન. અને તે કહેવતોનો પ્રભાવ મોટા વ્યક્તિઓથી લઈ નાના ભૂલકાઓ ઉપર પણ છે. ગુજરાતીમાં તમામ કહેવતો પૈકી અમુક કહેવતો માનવોના હોઠ ઉપર સ્થાન પ્રાપ્ત કરી ચુકી છે. અને આ જ કહેવતોમાં આપની એક કહેવત છે કે , ” ગોળ વિના મોળો કંસાર, માં વિના સૂનો સંસાર “. આ કહેવતની પ્રથમ પંક્તિ સાંભળતાની સાથે જ તેના પછીની પંક્તિનું સ્મરણ થઇ જાય. આમ આપની કહેવતોનો પ્રભાવ બાળપણથી જ મારી ઉપર રહ્યો છે. 

           પ્રેમાનંદજી, હું મારા લેખ લખવાના શોખને તમારા પ્રેરણામય જીવનની બસ એક ચિનગારી આપી શકીશ તો પણ મારું જીવન ધન્ય થશે. ગુજરાતી ભાષા સાથેનો આપનો લગાવ મને એક ગુજરાતી હોવા ઉપર ગર્વ અપાવે છે.

 

– આપની જિજ્ઞાસુ

Sakshi Patel

content.rendered:
In India, marriage is a very auspicious occasion. There are festive occasions in India, and in most cases celebrated with extensive decorations, color, music, dance, costumes, and rituals that depend on the community, region, and religion of the bride and the groom, as well as their preferences. India celebrates about 10 million weddings per year, of which about 80% are Hindu weddings.

I guess most of us are curious about the rituals and why they are performed. I was also curious to know more about these rituals and thus asked my grandparents. They explained a lot to me. Everyone knows that the darker the bride’s mehndi, the stronger her marriage will be! Another belief is that if the Mehendi lasts longer in the hands of the bride than her fiancé, she’ll be loved a lot by her in-laws! Weird, right? So the actual reason why mehndi is applied is that it calms the nerves and keeps the body from becoming tense. Plus you will be surprised to know that Mehendi is a highly antiseptic agent which can protect you from viral diseases. Our ancestors were very superior in terms of science and religion. Every ritual introduced by them is based on a scientific reasons. I was also surprised when I heard about the vermillion. Apart from being the symbol of matrimony for a Hindu woman, sindoor (red vermilion powder) has some great health benefits as well. It contains turmeric, lime, and a minute level of the metal mercury. So, when it’s applied to the hair partition, the mercury cools down the body and makes you feel relaxed.

Most of the rituals have some reasons whereas some of them are superstitious. I couldn’t stop laughing when I heard about the wedding outfits. The reason couples are always discouraged from lending their wedding dress to someone is that it may bring the borrower good luck, but this generosity can bring bad omen to lenders. So, if you are thinking about lending your wedding dress to someone else then I say think again.

Weddings are one of those rare occasions when Indian parents let their kids loose and are not that strict. That’s the most fun part. Who needs an orchestra? When it comes to Indian weddings, it’s the aunties with their dholaks and chamchas all the way! Not to forget the impromptu ‘rishta’ pairings. Uncles and aunties are always hunting for suitable grooms or brides for their single kids.

In a lot of traditions, the bride’s mother playfully catches the groom’s nose – this is to remind him to always treat her daughter well. A similar ceremony exists in Marathi weddings called ‘kaanapalli’, where the bride’s brother playfully twists the groom’s ear to extract a similar promise from the groom. Funny, isn’t it?

There are weddings and then there are Indian weddings, and it makes a hell of a lot of a difference when you get to be a part of them. Indian wedding is an endless food fare. I enjoy being a guest in wedding because of the exotic cuisine arranged by the families of bride and groom. There is no denying, Indians love to eat and prepare some fancy and flavorsome dishes. Of course, the wedding time when the hosts prepare the best dishes of the region along with the popular dishes in India to treat their guests with an unsurpassed gastronomic experience. This is the reason why I love to attend the wedding!

Gautam Gandhi

title.rendered: Manushi Malhotra’s Murdercase- Part01 Arrival of Detective Vijay

content.rendered:
Manushi Malhotra’s case was on the verge of getting closed.

Vadodara was seeing chaos every day. People were living in fear and angst. Unfortunately, due to lack of evidence and witnesses, even this case was going to the pile of unsolved cases registered in Vadodara. Ten murders were committed in a short span of 2months.

Aditya, the head officer of Vadodara Police Department was disappointed and disgusted by his department’s inefficiency to bring justice for his people. In reality, he was unable to accept his failure.

He walks out of the station and takes a quick drag from his Marlboro. Trying to stabilise his anger. Patil who was the constable of VPD(Vadodara Police Department) calls Aditya back to the police station.

“Sir, it’s the state investigation agency on the line.

“again!”

It was the consecutive calling from the investigation which pissed him off.

He takes a quick drag and walks back to answer the call.

“Mr Aditya, This is Vivek Rathod, commissioner of State Investigation Agency(SIA).

It looks like you are not able to slay the demons of your town.”

Rathod’s voice was fruity with an authoritative tone.

“Sir I think I will be able to handle it if you give me some more time…”

“I am sending one of my detectives to help you out. I hope you and VPD will cooperate. Thank you.”

Without waiting for a response, Rathod ended the call. Aditya banged his fist ferociously on the table.

Anyone could guess that he was cussing Rathod in his thoughts very badly.

“I don’t understand how can someone be so arrogant! They don’t know anything about our city. This officer from SIA will waste our freaking time and nothing else.”

Patil took a deep breath and replied “Sir but we have to solve this case as soon as possible and some help wouldn’t be that bad. Right sir?

“I think you are right, Patil. I am pushing myself and the whole staff mercilessly”

 

The next day

Vijay Shekhawat hopped out from his matt black BMW which had the SIA logo on its windshield.

Combining his wide upper frame with his 5’11 tall stature, Vijay looked like a man of authority and integrity. A scar above his eye was making him look more barbarous. His smile was in complete contrast with his personality. No matter how manly he looked, his smile was childish, full of innocence.

“I am Aditya, Head officer of VPD.

” Vijay Shekhawat senior detective at SIA. let’s start the meeting, we are already running short with time.”

 

Case briefing session at VPD(Vadodara Police Department)

Aditya took a deep breath and started describing the crucial information related to the case.

“What we are looking at here is Manushi Malhotra’s murder case which according to the forensic report took place on 20th November. Her body was first seen by a local delivery boy. Nothing important came through his interrogation. She was an orphan and had a husband with whom she separated 2 years back. Her husband left the country in the same month they got separated. She had some casual friends but they didn’t know anything about Manushi’s personal life. According to reports, no fingerprints were found near the body. Her wound tells us that she was stabbed with a sharp knife or Katana which pierced her belly. Loss of blood was the reason behind her death. We checked the house, nothing critical for this case was found.”


“What are your thoughts on this, Vijay”

Vijay was about to speak something but got interrupted by Aditya. He went on in with his exhausted voice, ” Please don’t think that the delivery boy might have killed her, emptied her locker and acted as a spectator which will make him the least suspected person. Guess what, we have already searched his house plus his recent bank transactions. He is clear.


“No, I was going to say…” Vijay tried to speak but was again interrupted by Aaditya.

” Oh, So you might be thinking that his Husband with whom she ended with a rough note might have come to seek his revenge. Like the old revenge stories, huh? Then listen, He was in the state when the crime was committed! But guess what he was staying in a place 300km away. My team checked the CCTVs of the hotel in which he was staying. They found nothing suspicious at all.

I am telling you, Vijay, this is pretty bad. You don’t even know how much time and energy I have wasted behind this dead-end case.” Aditya took a quick sip from his energy drink and sat down. Vijay stood up and went near the whiteboard on which information related to some other cases were written. He rubbed it out and started writing something. He wrote three words in bold handwriting, circling each word heavily.


ORPHAN              DIVORCE                   LONELY


She was an orphan which means she never got a family who loves her. The Love one gets from his mother when she feeds him. She never had a father whose mere existence can make you feel protected and secured. The care and warmth one gets when the whole family is around. The relationship one sees between their parents who might not have a cosy romantic bond but they still managed to hold their hands through disastrous times. And that is more romantic and beautiful than anything else.


“You know what type of trauma is the worst?

The trauma which sparkles the wrath of past traumas”

Life downcast her once again. When she got divorced. Incidence like this impacts everyone but imagine the misery it would have created in Manushi’s life. Whose past life was already messed up? Even the toughest cookie breaks after going through such type of heartbreaking, heart-wrenching and distressful experience. After all this ruckus she was alone in her life.No matter how ignorant some people are who fantasize about loneliness and Lone-wolf crap. Deep down we all know, all of us want to be loved and nothing else.

Everyone in the room was dumbstruck and amazed by Vijay’s theory on the on-going case. Though he was poetic while explaining his views, the facts remain the same. He was right.

“Check her medical records. Don’t just rely on the documents, interrogate her neighbours about her daily routine. She must have taken some medical help. From my point of view, she might be seeing some therapist. I want your team to work relentlessly to find this person. Are you clear, Mr Aditya?”Aditya was confused and astonished after listening to Vijay’s take on the case. Still, there was something that was bothering Aditya. He was sweating heavily and taking deep breaths.No matter how hard he was trying to show that he was happy that they were progressing with the case. His face was telling a different story as for a few seconds he was clearly not happy with the revelation. As if some secret which was meant to be forgotten became alive suddenly. He quickly puts on his fake smile and replies” Yes sir, I will make sure that we find this person as soon as possible.”


Is Aditya hiding something? Is it related to this case?

Did he know Manushi before she got murdered? Will Vijay be able to solve this? Is the stranger( Manushi’s therapist) connected to this case? What will happen next?

Only time will tell. The answers to Manushi’s present lies in the past.

Pruthvirajsinh Gohil

MH 4th Sem

Vishesh Waghela

content.rendered:
Engineers at the University of California San Diego have created a four-legged soft robot that doesn’t need any electronics to work. The robot requires a constant source of pressurized air for all its tasks, including its controls and locomotion systems.

Soft Robot requires complex components like circuit boards, valves, and pumps –outside the robot’s body. The components, that constitute the robot’s brains and nervous system, are commonly bulky and expensive. Whereas the UC San Diego robot is controlled by a lightweight, low-cost system of pneumatic circuits, made up of tubes and soft valves, onboard the robot itself. The robot can walk on command or in response to signals it senses from the environment.

The robot’s computational ability mimics mammalian reflexes. Those are driven by a neural response from the spine rather than the brain. The team was inspired by neural circuits found in animals, called “central pattern generators”. It comprises very simple elements that can yield rhythmic patterns to control motions like walking and running. “This work represents a fundamental yet significant step towards fully-autonomous, electronics-free walking robots,” says, a Ph.D. student of UC.

The robot is equipped with three valves acting as inverters that cause a high-pressure state to spread around the air-powered circuit. The robot’s four legs have three degrees of freedom powered by three muscles. They are angled downward at 45 degrees. It is composed of three parallel, connected pneumatic cylindrical chambers with bellows. When a chamber is pressurized, the limb bends in the opposite direction. That affects, the multi-axis bending coerced for walking. Researchers paired chambers from each leg diagonally across from one another, facilitating the control problem.

A soft valve switches the direction of rotation of the limbs between counterclockwise and clockwise. That valve acts as what’s known as a latching double pole, double throw switch — a switch with two inputs and four outputs, so each input has two corresponding outputs it’s connected to. That mechanism is a little like taking two nerves and swapping their connections in the brain. In the future, researchers want to improve the robot’s gait so it can walk on natural terrains and uneven surfaces. This would allow the robot to navigate over a variety of obstacles.

Muskan Vora

content.rendered:
Jonas, the scared teen who is stuck in and out of cycles of the most undervalued concept: time. I have seen your best times and the worst times and everything from the beginning of your story and the end, how quickly you grew up. I refuse to comment on your moral picture, but I may be able to help you with all the glitches in your mind.

I write, not to judge anyone or reveal things prematurely, but to leave a piece of me with you in such testing times. Please follow my requests, and your journey will be smooth. It’s unfair of me to tell you how you’ll be going ahead with a backward push but hold your breath and count to ten and it’ll be 10 more times you’ve missed a chance.

Your dad is dead, and I understand the pain, the dread of not knowing. But everything happens for a reason. Or that every reason needs a task. My words are just brushing the edge of all that there is to know, and of all people, I hate being played with words. So, I’ll give you some hard facts.

You need to be emotionally stable, because 1 mistake and you’ll end up as a villain. You need to let go of your ego because knowledge will be your biggest curse. And above all, refrain from anything that goes against love.

To say you’ll have a happening life is such an understatement, but your childish innocence will handle it all. I see you and I see such a brave man. You inspire me when you take your younger self out to a world that is completely bizarre. You create an example for me when you take up the initiative and start something new. But the most intense thing I was amazed at you for, was to love, through centuries and miles away, and know that it is the only thing that’s true.

 

Love,

Dhruv

Gautam Gandhi

IT 4th Sem

<p><span lang="EN-US">Goodbye! It is such a self-contradictory
word. How is bidding farewell to something or someone even good? Or is it? Why
do we need to say goodbye to the things we are most attached to? For instance,
childhood. Everyone’s favorite phase of life, filled with so much rejoice and
excitement and cute innocence. But then puberty hits, and it might have hit
hard to a few of us, leaving us no choice except to say goodbye. A humongous
list pops out in my mind whenever I think of things that have been an integral
part of my life but had to bid goodbye even for a moment or two if not forever.
Like those crazy, full-of-life days with school friends, insane bike rides in
the town, chess and badminton games with papa, our old house which turned into
a home then, and a very recent one – our hostels and colleges. How can I forget
how much I miss the fights with my sibling too? Oh no, okay, I still do that –
the only constant encountered so far. Just kidding! </span></p>

<p><span lang="EN-US"> </span></p>

<p><span style="color:black" lang="EN-US">Do you remember a time
when you had to say goodbye to someone who has been your ride-or-die person,
your come-hell-or-high water person, your lobster, be it your best friend,
cousin, family member, significant other, or anyone? Goodbyes are goddamn hard
at that point, right? It sounds dreadful that someone who mattered to you more
than your life is no longer with you, either for some time or maybe forever.
Please, don’t kill me for saying this, but what if I say we should be grateful
for this? For what? For having someone with whom you cherished lifelong
memories which will always blossom in your heart. For finding your forever. A
few people have the privilege of meeting their forever type of person, and if
we are one of them, we should be grateful for that. We are so lucky if we have
met someone who makes goodbyes the hardest. If that is something we are not
grateful for, I don’t know for what else we would be? We cannot keep all the
gifts of life. </span><span lang="EN-US">Some things<span style="color:black"> we
are just lent. This reminds me of lines, <i style="mso-bidi-font-style:normal">Muskuraye
toh Muskurane ke karz utaarne honge</i>. The brutal truth is we are the only
guaranteed forever in our life.<span style="mso-spacerun:yes">  </span></span></span></p>

<p><span style="color:black" lang="EN-US"><span style="mso-spacerun:yes"> </span></span></p>

<p><span lang="EN-US">You must be pondering then why the word
includes “good” in it? Sometimes goodbyes can be the gateway to growth. A
courageous leap into the new beginning. There will always be something lying in
front of us that will be much more than what we’ve lost – a person, a memory,
or that lingering bad habit. If we’ll keep re-reading that old chapter – being
the same old us, never trying to upgrade, how will we be able to move to the
next better chapter – better us? So, let us all say goodbye to the normal and
hello to the extraordinary. I guess debate on this word will be never-ending. I
will always have a love-hate relationship with this word. What are your
views?<span style="mso-spacerun:yes">  </span></span></p></div>

“So Mr. Pratik the final arrangements have been made. All that’s left is a signature from the new proprietors and the house will be all set to be sold. I must say, it’s a really pretty house you have. You must be having some really fond memories with it.” Said the real estate agent.

“Well not really. It’s a fact that I lived for 20 years in this house. But now that both mom and dad have passed away it’s just a liability I would like to be relieved of as soon as possible. It’s not worth holding on to stuff that’s no longer useful. Especially an old house with no one to call its own.” Replied Pratik with a smirk on his face.

Later that night Pratik went into a deep slumber. He suddenly woke outside the gate of his old house. In front of him, he saw a hooded man staring at the house. “Stand up young man.” He said as he stared at the house.

Pratik stood up. He looked at the house, it was the same house yet it had an aura of unrest surrounding it. The skies were filled with rumbling thunderclouds with the sound of the grasshoppers following them from every direction. Pratik hesitatingly inquired, “Why am I here? What am I doing outside this rusty old house.”

“Speak less and follow me the sooner we are done here the sooner you will be free. And do not try to walk away from me for if you are lost even I will never be able to find you.” Said the hooded man as he opened the gates of the old house. Pratik followed him and the man took him to the hall first.

There he saw a man dressed in a cowboy suit. “ Ahoy Pratik boy, long time no see.” Seeing his face Pratik instantly remembered a TV show he used to watch with his family.

“I know you must be confused, but I am only here to take you down the Hall’s memory lane. Remember how you used to watch TV here with your mom and dad.”

Then Pratik suddenly had a flashback of how he slept on his mom’s lap while watching the show and how his dad carried him to the bedroom. “Oh, the pleasure it gave me seeing you all together.” He said as he covered his tearful eyes with his hat. Pratik had a confused yet sorrowful look in his eyes.

“Come with me. The journey’s not over.” The hooded man said and took him to the kitchen. There a woman in the dress of a waitress was waiting for them.

“Oh look how skinny you have become. Seems like you haven’t been eating good food since you left…..” And she continued rambling about his health for the next 10 minutes without catching a breath.

Then she said “Oh look at the time. I am sorry.” Here have a look at what I wish to show you.” She showed him the memory of his birthday and a cake baked by his mother for him with the bliss of innocent happiness on his face.

“Your mom and dad may not have earned as much as you have throughout their life, but they surely had a lot of wealth to purchase happiness. Take care of yourself, young man.” She said as she placed the palm of her hand on his cheek.

“Why are you showing me all this? What is the meaning of all this?” he yelled at the hooded man as he sat down grabbing his hair in a state of confusion. “You shall receive all the answers at the end of the journey.” The hooded man replied calmly.

He then took him to the garden. There he saw an old man who wore a hat and held pruners in his hands looking exactly like a gardener staring at the sky. “Seems like my turn has finally come. You know the drill.”

The gardener walked up to him, held his hand and showed him a memory of the day he tried the garden swing for the first time and grazed his knee. “During your first time, you increased the speed of the swing so much that you lost your balance at a height and fell. You cried a lot that day kid but so did I.” he sighed and continued staring at the clouds.

“So who’s next?” Pratik inquired in a gloomy tone as his conscious began to prick him as he tried holding his tears back. “We are close to the end.” Replied the man.

They then went to his bedroom. There they saw a man who looked exactly like his favourite action figure. “Welcome to the final room kid. Remember me, the red ranger. Your favourite hero. You always hanged my poster on your wall.”

He then looked into his eyes and showed him the final memory. The final part was filled with glimpses that brought tears to his eyes. “I have witnessed it all kid. Your heartbreaks, your sickness, your lonesome tears, your struggle everything. I have seen the version of you the world will never witness. Look at those thunderclouds!”

He pointed towards the window. “Even though the sky is covered by those dark clouds it doesn’t mean the stars aren’t there. And we have a lot of faith in our star.” He added as he looked at the hooded man with a smile. The man turned his face away from him.

“But….” Just as he was about to say something he was suddenly teleported outside his house again and was surrounded by those four people again.

“Wait a minute, what is all this? This is all too hard for me to process. Were you guys alive the entire time? And more importantly what are you? Please, someone, tell me something.” He wailed with tears dripping from his eyes as his words were eaten by his overflowing emotions.

“We are the spirits kid. The very manifestation of the emotions that your parents filled this house with.” Said the cowboy. “You were about to leave us and that made us really sad.” Said the maid. “Of course we knew this day would surely come.” added the gardener. “But all we wanted was for you to leave with happy memories and not discontent towards us. We all wish for your progress. But in return, all we demand is a proper farewell.” Said the superhero.

“I am sorry. I am sorry for everything I said. For ever mistreating you. And thank you so much for staying by my side all these years.” Said Pratik with his hands joined and tears flowing down his eyes.

“I understand them all but, who are you hooded guy?” he asked. “ I am the very creator of this house Pratty and frankly I am proud of the way you have grown. Its time for you to return. Goodbye. Don’t forget I am always watching your back” He said in a different yet warm and familiar voice.

“Pratty, there is only one man in this world who called me that.” He exclaimed. Suddenly the ground beneath him opened up and he fell down into the darkness. He yelled “ Daaaadd…..” as he fell down.

When he finally woke up, he was perspiring as if he had run a 400 m race. Then he realized that whatever happened, it all occurred in his dream. He started crying again and went back to the house.

There he spent an hour in every room reliving his past. And finally, before selling the house he refurbished every room as if it were his own. In the end, he bid a final farewell to his old home with all the respect and love it deserved.

Mufaddal Suratwala

IT 4th Sem

Far from the central doab lied one of the largest valleys of Asia, the Sutkan valley. Sutkan Valley was one of the least travelled places due to its dangerous roads and the cursed town of Sutkan Valley which was feared even by the bravest of men. Nayannagar, the cursed town which lied in the middle of Sutkan Valley got its moniker after it was cursed by the God of Light. Kirtan was walking alone through this valley after a storm took him away from his crew members. He was afraid but the fact that he was going towards a cursed town intrigued him a lot. Though he was a scholar in various fields and a courtier of Kumbhal State, he was always ready to learn more. After getting rejected by quite a few merchants who were travelling through the same route, he decided to enter the cursed town to find a coachman who could take him to his house. He was astonished after seeing the marvelous fortress which lied in front of his eyes. As he entered the first thing which he saw was a huge rectangular stone on which words inscribed deeply. All this was carved on the board with golden colour making it more enormous and important. The statements inscribed on it were

” WE ARE GRATEFUL FOR THE KAMANAS.” ” 50 MORE YEARS TO COMPLETE OUR CURSE”

” WE ARE SORRY FOR OUR PAST MISTAKES, WE ARE BLESSED TO HAVE THE KAMANAS AS OUR RULING CLAN”

” THE MORE WE SERVE, THE MORE WE SEE”

Kirtan was shivering after reading the statements mentioned on the board. He knew the story about this town was not ridiculous. He knew something was wrong with this town. At the first sight nothing appeared strange about the place, like every other town there were small huts made from bricks and stones, farmers coming from their daily work, small children playing with sheep and goats. But the curse made all the difference. A long time ago, when Nayannagar was flourishing in trading with the nearby states and was bringing a lot of wealth to their King. One of the natives tried to enter in the citadel (a place where the kamanas used to stay) and stole gold coins from them. At that time Lentiqua ( God of Light) came and cursed the people of Nayannagar that you all will live in darkness and whoever will see the light of day or night would suffer pain which would be intolerable. “Wear a black patch around your eyes, live in darkness, your coming generation will also remain curse and this will go on for 100years.”

Kirtan remembered how people were afraid of Lentiqua in his state too. Even the kings with much bigger army use to think twice before doing anything against the ruling king of Nayannagar.

What surprised Kirtan was the ability of people to work in harmony even though their eyes were covered with a black patch. He saw a person riding a bullock cart with so much ease and comfort. He was dumbstruck by seeing the capability of the villagers to work without having the power to see anything. As soon as he went in the main market of the Village, he saw board praising the KAMANAS in various ways

Our ancestral curse could be withdrawn if we will serve the people of citadel relentlessly.

Their eyes are our eyes.

If I will try to remove my patch, the curse will still affect my children.

These statements were inscribed in a braille writing method so that the blind could read it. Everyone had to read it as a part of their daily routine. Kirtan was already in awe with the weirdness of this town.

As he was tired and there was no cartman which could take him to his state. He decides to stay in Nayanngar for the rest of the day. After having his dinner he was roaming near the market when a man started acting as if he was going through a lot of pain. He was running here and there, throwing things which were around him and mumbling something which no one was able to understand properly.

“I just don’t understand what is wrong with the youth, they think they are very smart. See what happens when you test your smartness against God.”

“He tried to remove his black patch! That’s why Lentiqua punished his soul!”

Unable to understand the situation, everyone was giving their opinions based on what they think the situation was but due to the fear of Lentiqua, everyone was terrified.

There was fear, anger and a lot of ignorance.

In a few minutes, The kamanas came with their guards and took the man inside their citadel to treat him even though there was no treatment, just some ailments which could reduce the pain before the body gives up. Kirtan was terrified after seeing this, till now he didn’t believe in Lentiqua completely but after seeing what happened in front of his eyes, he was sure that the legend of Lentiqua is not a fad but a real freaking thing. He went asleep after all the ruckus ended. After having a good sleep, he woke up at 4:00am so that he could start his journey as soon as possible.

As no cartman were available that early, he started searching for some help near the citadel (a place where the kamanas lived). He was about to pull the gate when he heard a familiar voice coming from a house inside the citadel. Unable to recall whose voice was it, he tries to be as close to the house as possible so that he could listen properly to what they are talking. Indeed it was the same man who was possessed by Lentiqua yesterday.

“They are fools!”

“Yes, You are right and the credit goes to our King who used an unreal nonexistent legend to manipulate the people so that they work for us without asking any questions.”

“Exactly and we just have to enact this act of getting possessed by Lentiqua. So that no one ever tries to remove the black patch. Fear could drive people crazy.”

Kirtan was still not able to believe what he just heard, what should he believe now?

The ugly truth which questions the purity of humans and how far they could go to fulfil their desires or The beautiful fictional story of Lentiqua which made life a living hell for the villagers. A lie which forever implanted fear and ignorance in their minds. A lie which made them slaves both physically and mentally. He decided that he will bring the truth to their lives, he will bring the light in their life once again. He was about to run from the citadel so that he could tell the truth when a native Kamana saw him and stabbed him to death. “He was being possessed by Lentiqua last night and due to his intolerable act of vandalising our property and his failed attempt to steal from us, he was being killed last night.” This is how the news was communicated to the villagers. For them

he was just another crazy man who tried to outsmart the God of Light, Lentiqua…

Don’t let your belief to overshadow what is true and real.

If you are not manipulating the society then you are getting manipulated by the society

Pruthviraj Gohil

IT 4th Sem

Ammara Ahmed

MBBS 2nd year

I have been watching many movies recently because of staying at home! Before a month or two I watched a movie named ‘Jhalki’ which was based on the story of an elder sister and his little kid brother who was dragged into the world of bonded labor. In that movie, I came to know about you, Boman Irani sir played your role in the movie. It inspired me a lot and I started searching for more about your deeds!

I found it quite amusing that I was ignorant of a personality like you. Gradually I came to know that you campaigned against child labor in India and advocated the universal right to education! In 2014 you were the co-recipient of the Nobel Peace Prize along with Malala Yousafzai for your struggle against the suppression of children and young people and the right of all children to education.

In one of your interviews, I came to know that your exceptionally idealistic and helpful nature was inculcated by your mother. It was very disheartening to hear that you had such a tough childhood. You were significantly affected by the lack of school access for all children. Even though you managed to become a lecturer in your early days. Your experiences of poverty in your childhood made you a fine man which is now admired by everyone around you.

You gave up your career as an electrical engineer and then founded the ‘Bachpan Bachao Andolan’ (Save Childhood Movement), conceived and led the Global March against Child Labour and its International advocacy body, the International Center on Child Labor and Education (ICCLE). When I noticed your exquisite works, somewhere in my heart I felt like I should also do something for society. Your ‘Bachpan Bachao Andolan’ and GoodWeave International captured my attention to a great extent! In one of your interviews, you told that the movement identifies, liberates, rehabilitates, and educates the victims of child labor, trafficking, ethical trade, and much more. Many child-friendly villages are your creations. Your GoodWeave International is very much active in the eradication of child labor in the rug-making industry.

You said that you remember your mother and father the most. Your mother saw you being attacked. Just like every mother she also cried when you left your engineering for this cause. But still, your parents encouraged you! In one of your interviews, you told that the victims of child abuse told you that they weren’t kids anymore because of the events that happened to them which were unforgivable. Although you helped them out of their trauma so nicely. You addressed everyone that we all should befriend the children. No one should see them as pitiable subjects. People often relate childish behavior to stupidity or foolishness. This attitude needs to be changed!

I am looking forward to reading your books! Will for Children, Because Words Matter, Every Child Matters, and The light of the Same Sun are your masterpieces of literature! You not only inspire me from books but also from your quotes. “The single aim of my life is that every child is:

free to be a child,

free to grow and develop,

free to eat, sleep, see daylight,

free to laugh and cry,

free to play,

free to learn, free to go to school, and above all, free to dream.”

Your this way of thinking compelled me to write you an open letter. In the end, I would like to pass on the message which you preached, we should never ignore or let go of the malpractices of child abuse or child labor within our sight and should take a stand for anything happening around us.

Gautam Gandhi

AUTHOR
IT 3rd Sem

Meet Mehta

content.rendered:
Nothing ever dies an ultimate death in middle-class families. Probably the toothpaste hack is the most famous one wherein toothpaste is dissected and used until the inner surface shines vibrantly. Indian mothers are known for recycling things. You never know that the Holi colors once you used could be used again on Diwali. Every single thing is saved from being disposed of by saying “It might be helpful soon”.

Once upon a time disciple of Buddha asked for a new robe. Buddha questioned that what you did with the old robe. Disciple answered, “I made a curtain out of it”.  What about the old curtain? Buddha asked. “Oh, that I converted into a bedsheet”. And the old bed sheet? “I made mop out of it”. And the mop? “Dear Lord mops was in the stranded form so I made wicks out of it and I light it up every evening”. Buddha smiled upon the enlightenment of his disciple. That disciple is none other than an Indian Mother. When kanjoosi went abroad for studying it returned as sustainability. What was considered cheap then is now cool! Recycling is seen everywhere and at every step. The newspaper becomes book covers and glossy magazines are turned into a cone for eating mouth-watering bhel. If jeans were torn off then they get a makeover as shorts. However, now Ripped jeans are a style statement.

Every middle-class kid would have felt embarrassed because of the thrifty ways of their mom. It’s just that after we started using phones we came to know that those DIY videos were inspired by our household’s methods. Being frugal is considered cool but without economic restrictions. They might have been raised under tough economic situations so they value money and things bought. Throwing away things is just not their cup of tea. “It cannot be thrown so it must be reused!” It’s their perfect ideology for sustainability.

Try entering the kitchen and their mindful hacks will blow your mind! Leftover rice gets refurbished into mouthwatering cutlets. Pav bhaji was originally a mesh of leftover veggies. This art of recycling and reusing is every environmentalist’s dream. Save- the-planet folks must appoint Indian Mom as president. It’s no longer being a miser but it’s all about being #woken_up.

 

 

 

Muskan Vora

AUTHOR
EC 4th Sem

Kaushal Parmar

DESIGNER
IC 5th Sem
